circuit breakers there's protocol handling there's security there's error

harder than locally based computing systems and that are and science of

a big problem which is that they don't fit neatly and nicely into a developer

because I think that's probably enough for the webinar just can talk through a few other things that you can do so one
of the the patterns that's very common in building distributed systems is something called a circuit breaker so
for instance suppose I want to instead of me writing the status I want to go and grab us a quote from Homer Simpson
and then I want to tweet that quote now suppose that Homer Simpson quote service
goes down what typically happens in a distributed system is that though these
servers that are that are trying to call another server they retry they expect
failure and they retry so you you expect that remote services might go down and
when they do you treat retry them the problem with that is that if that Homer
Simpson quote service goes down and now I have a whole cluster of servers trying
it they're already trying it the minute it comes back up it's going to be hammered and it's gonna go down again
instantly so the circuit breaker pattern basically says that if that service goes
down I'm going to give it time to recover before sending requests to it
again and that's a circuit breaker let me just quickly show you what that looks
like so if I and this is
very similar code to what we've just seen it's got the same tweeter it's got the same listener hears my Homer Simpson
quote service and I have a circuit breaker that basically says I have a
rolling window of ten seconds and every second I'm gonna have a bucket and if I
get any failures at all I'm gonna give it three seconds to back off before coming back and I gotta treat a
one-second delay as being that the service is down so in this model it's
really really easy and I can show you that the sequence diagram for that I'm basically gonna try and get that quote
because it's got the circuit breaker it's going to automatically use the
